content: Regulation is a fundamental government function, with federal agencies issuing thousands of rules annually on various topics. The costs of complying with these regulations are not included in the federal budget process, prompting some policymakers to consider measuring total regulatory costs and benefits. For example, the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Creation and Sunset and Review Act of 2011 aims to require an annual report on regulatory costs and benefits. The Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Creation and Sunset and Review Act of 2011 would establish an office to issue an annual report on the total costs and benefits of existing Federal regulations. However, measuring these costs and benefits is challenging due to the need to determine baselines and aggregate results from studies conducted with different methodologies. The Office of Advocacy within the Small Business Administration released a report in September 2010 stating that the annual cost of federal regulations in 2008 was about $1.75 trillion. This was the fourth report prepared for the SBA Office of Advocacy in the previous 15 years. In the previous 15 years, estimates of annual federal regulatory costs ranged from $416 billion to $1.75 trillion. The $1.75 trillion estimate has been widely cited as evidence for regulatory reform legislation and oversight actions, although some critics argue it overstates the total cost of regulations. The $1.75 trillion estimate of federal regulatory costs in 2008 by Crain and Crain has been criticized for overstating the total cost. It includes economic regulations, environmental regulations, tax compliance, and regulations for safety and security. The estimated cost of economic regulations in 2008 was more than 70% of the total regulatory costs, according to the Crain and Crain report. Economic regulations impact businesses by affecting what products and services they produce, how they produce them, and how they are priced and marketed. These regulations also influence domestic and international business operations, including quotas and tariffs on foreign imports. The Crain and Crain report estimated that economic regulations in 2008 accounted for over 70% of total regulatory costs. These regulations impact businesses by affecting production, pricing, and marketing of products and services, as well as domestic and international operations, including quotas and tariffs on foreign imports. The report used the Worldwide Governance Index (WGI) of regulatory quality to measure governments' ability to implement policies that promote private sector development. In 2008, the WGI regulatory quality index score for the United States was +1.579. Crain and Crain used regression analysis to determine the impact of changes in the regulatory quality index on real GDP per capita, holding constant four other variables. Crain and Crain found that a one-unit change in the WGI regulatory quality index corresponded to a 9.4% change in real GDP per capita. The difference between the US regulatory quality index in 2008 and the maximum value of +2.5 resulted in an 8.7% reduction in GDP due to economic regulations. This reduction affected the real GDP per capita in the United States, which was approximately $14.2 trillion in 2008.
